Identification.ShortTitle: Yukon Territory Supreme Court Rules for Pre-Hearing Conferences in Criminal Matters
Identification.LongTitle: Rules of the Supreme Court of the Yukon Territory for Pre-Hearing Conferences Held Pursuant to Section 553.1 of the Criminal Code

Provision.Text: The Supreme Court of the Yukon Territory, pursuant to section 438* of the Criminal Code and with the concurrence of a majority of the judges thereof present at a meeting held for the purpose on July 25, 1988, hereby makes the annexed Rules of the Supreme Court of the Yukon Territory for pre-hearing conferences held pursuant to section 553.1 of the Criminal Code.

SignatureTitle.Emphasis: Chief Judge of the Supreme Court of the Yukon Territory

Section.Text: These Rules may be cited as the Yukon Territory Supreme Court Rules for Pre-Hearing Conferences in Criminal Matters.

Definition.Text: Court means the Supreme Court of the Yukon Territory; (Cour)
judge means a judge of the Court. (juge)

Section.Text: A pre-hearing conference shall be held at such time and date and in such place and manner as a judge may direct, or at such further dates, times and places as the judge who presides at the pre-hearing conference may direct.

Unless otherwise ordered by the judge who presides at the pre-hearing conference, the pre-hearing conference shall be an informal meeting conducted in chambers at which a full and free discussion of the issues raised may occur without prejudice to the rights of the parties in any proceedings thereafter taking place.

Unless otherwise ordered by a judge, counsel for the Crown and counsel for the accused, each fully briefed in respect of the issues to be discussed at the pre-hearing conference, or, in the case of an accused who is not represented by counsel, the accused, shall be present at the pre-hearing conference.
A judge may require that an accused, represented by counsel, be available for consultation with counsel in respect of matters to be considered at the pre-hearing conference.
Without restricting the generality of Rule 3 or 4, the judge who presides at a pre-hearing conference may inquire into and discuss

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the extent of disclosure made by the Crown and any further requests therefor by an accused or counsel for an accused;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the possibility of resolution of any or all of the issues in the proceeding, including the possible disposition of any or all counts contained in the indictment, whether by plea of guilty or otherwise;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the simplification of such issues as remain to be litigated at trial;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the possibility of obtaining admissions and agreements so as to facilitate a fair, just and expeditious determination of the proceedings;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the estimated duration of the trial;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the advisability of fixing a date for trial where one is not already fixed; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: any other matter that may assist in promoting a fair, just, and expeditious trial including the holding of further pre-hearing conferences.

Section.Text: The judge who presides at a pre-hearing conference may, at the discretion of the judge, direct that an anticipated pre-hearing motion be heard prior to the date fixed for trial, at such time and date as the Court deems fit or at such other time and date as may be convenient for counsel and the Court.

The judge who presides at a pre-hearing conference may make such other orders as the judge considers to be necessary and appropriate having regard to all the circumstances, in order to promote a fair, just and expeditious pre-hearing conference and trial.
On completion of a pre-hearing conference, the judge who presides at the pre-hearing conference

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: may complete a Pre-Hearing Conference Report in Form I, a copy of which shall be provided to counsel for the Crown and counsel for the accused or the accused if the accused is not represented by counsel; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: shall endorse on a copy of the indictment the date upon which the pre-hearing conference was held.

Section.Text: Nothing in these Rules shall be construed or interpreted so as to preclude a judge from conducting, with the consent of counsel for the Crown and counsel for the accused, or, in the case of an accused who is not represented by counsel, the accused, such other informal pre-hearing conferences, in addition to the conference provided for in subsection 553.1(2) of the Criminal Code, on such terms as the judge considers fit.
These Rules shall come into force on the day section 553.1 of the Criminal Code, as enacted by section 127 of the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1985, S.C. 1985, c. 19, comes into force.

Footnote.Text: [Note: Rules in force September 1, 1988, see SI/88-125.]

Provision.Text: IN THE SUPREME COURT OF THE YUKON TERRITORY

NOTE: THE POSITIONS HEREIN ARE TENTATIVE. ALL AGREEMENTS ARE WITHOUT PREJUDICE AND PURELY FOR THE ASSISTANCE OF THE COURT IN THE RESOLUTION OF TRIAL PROBLEMS. IF ANY CHANGE BECOMES NECESSARY COUNSEL WILL ENDEAVOUR TO ADVISE EACH OTHER AND THE COURT PROMPTLY.
Date and length of preliminary inquiry:
Has a date been set for trial?

row.entry: If so, what is the date of the trial?

Provision.Text: Tentatively, how many days will the trial take?
Has the accused elected trial by
Will there be a re-election for trial by
If consent is required to permit re-election to be made, will consent by given?
Is the indictment or one or more counts thereof alleged to be legally insufficient having regard to

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: the provisions of subsection 510(1) of the Criminal Code?

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: the provisions of subsection 510(3) of the Criminal Code?
Has there been a request or demand for particulars?
Will there be a motion for particulars?
Will there be a request to amend the indictment or a count thereof?
Will there be a motion to sever the trial of certain counts from the trial of others?
Will there be a motion to sever the trial of certain accused from the trial of another [others]?
Will there be a challenge to the array?
Will prospective jurors be challenged for cause?
In the event of a challenge for cause, will counsel be submitting a list of proposed questions to be asked of the prospective jurors?
Will any of the special pleas be raised?
Has disclosure been made of any medical or other reports bearing on the issue of fitness
Will copies of such reports be made available to the trial judge?
Was fitness raised at the preliminary inquiry?
Will the issue of fitness be contested at trial
How long is the evidence on fitness reasonably expected to take?

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: Will evidence of similar facts be tendered for admission by the Crown?

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: Will admissibility be contested by the defence?

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: Will evidence be adduced of statements alleged to have been made by an accused to a person in authority?

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: On what basis will a voir dire be requested?

Provision.Label: (ii)
Provision.Text: non-compliance with section 10 of the Charter

Provision.Label: (c)
Provision.Text: How long is the voir dire reasonably expected to take?

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: Will the admissibility of any evidence be contested on the basis of the hearsay rule?

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: Will it be argued that any evidence proposed for admission qualifies as an exception to the hearsay rule?

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: Will opinion evidence by a duly qualified expert be tendered for admission?

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: Will any claim of privilege be asserted in respect of any evidence proposed for introduction

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: Will the admissibility of any evidence be contested on the basis that it constitutes a search or seizure within section 8 of the Charter?
Intercepted Private Communications And Their Derivatives

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: Will evidence of intercepted private communications be tendered for admission?

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: Will a voir dire be required to determine admissibility?

Provision.Label: (c)
Provision.Text: Will the evidence be alleged to be admissible pursuant to

Provision.Label: (d)
Provision.Text: Will the evidence be tendered for admission under

Provision.Label: (e)
Provision.Text: Will the adequacy of subsection 178.16(4) of the Criminal Code notice be contested?

Provision.Label: (f)
Provision.Text: In the voir dire to determine admissibility will any of the following applications be made?

Provision.Label: (i)
Provision.Text: an application to open the sealed packet under subparagraph 178.14(1)(a)(ii);

Provision.Label: (ii)
Provision.Text: an application to set aside an authorization;

Provision.Label: (iii)
Provision.Text: an application alleging fraud in the obtaining of an authorization;

Provision.Label: (iv)
Provision.Text: an application alleging that the interceptions were not made in accordance with an authorization; or

Provision.Label: (v)
Provision.Text: an application alleging that the consent was vitiated by coercion.

Provision.Label: (g)
Provision.Text: How long is the voir dire reasonably expected to take?

Provision.Label: (h)
Provision.Text: At the trial will there be any issue taken in respect of the following matters?

Provision.Label: (iii)
Provision.Text: the use of transcripts as an aid to understanding; or

Provision.Label: (iv)
Provision.Text: the admissibility of transcripts as exhibits.

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: Will it be alleged that any Crown witness

Provision.Label: (i)
Provision.Text: is incompetent to testify on account of age or lack of mental capacity?

Provision.Label: (ii)
Provision.Text: is capable only of giving unsworn testimony?

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: Will it be alleged that any defence witness

Provision.Label: (i)
Provision.Text: is incompetent to testify on account of age or lack of mental capacity?

Provision.Label: (ii)
Provision.Text: is capable only of giving unsworn testimony?

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: Is a directed verdict application likely at the end of the Crown’s case?

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: Are there any other procedural matters on which the trial judge will be asked to rule?

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: How long is the trial reasonably expected to take?

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: What is the Crown position on each accused?

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: On what legal basis does the Crown expect to establish the guilt of each accused?

Provision.Label: (i)
Provision.Text: the definition of the offence; Criminal Code provisions applicable:

Provision.Label: (ii)
Provision.Text: the basis of liability; Criminal Code provisions applicable:

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: What is the defence position on each accused?

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: Is it reasonably anticipated that any of the following defences may be raised?

Provision.Label: (c)
Provision.Text: Will the character of the victim be the subject-matter of evidence?

Provision.Label: (d)
Provision.Text: Will the character of the accused be the subject-matter of evidence?
